summary: This is an FBI 302 report summarizing an interview with DR. [redacted], the Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), conducted on August 29, 2019. The interview details the psychological intake, assessment, and monitoring of Jeffrey Epstein from his arrival at MCC on July 8, 2019, through the period leading up to his death, including a prior incident where he was found with a loose noose. The report provides insight into prison protocols, Epstein's behavior, and the psychologist's hypotheses about the noose incident.

persons.name: Dr. [redacted]
persons.role: Chief Psychologist at Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC)
persons.context: The primary interviewee who oversaw Jeffrey Epstein's psychological assessments and care at MCC. She details the intake process, suicide risk assessments, and her interactions with Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate at MCC facing sex offense charges. The document details his psychological assessments, behavior, complaints, and the July 23 incident where he was found with a loose noose.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein alleged Tartaglione tried to kill him and called him a pedophile, leading to hypotheses about the noose incident being an assault or 'gaming' the system.

persons.name: Dr. [redacted]
persons.role: National Suicide Prevention Coordinator from BOP Central Office
persons.context: Consulted by the Chief Psychologist regarding Epstein's housing. Recommended housing Epstein with a sex offender in SHU.

persons.name: Lt. [redacted]
persons.context: A lieutenant in the Special Housing Unit to whom the Chief Psychologist passed on Epstein's demands. Described as very regimented.

persons.name: Warden
persons.context: Part of the executive staff meetings where inmate status was discussed. Involved in the decision regarding Epstein's cellmate assignment.

persons.name: Associate Warden
persons.context: Part of the executive staff involved in meetings and the decision regarding Epstein's cellmate assignment.

connections.description: Chief Psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological assessments, suicide risk evaluations, and passing on his complaints to prison staff.
Were housed together in the SHU. Epstein alleged Tartaglione tried to kill him and called him a pedophile.
The Chief Psychologist consulted with the National Suicide Prevention Coordinator regarding Epstein's housing situation.
Epstein's attorney was present with him during some meetings and, along with Epstein, mocked the psychologist for thinking Epstein was suicidal.

events.title: Epstein's Intake at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at MCC and completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ). He marked nothing, but due to his high-profile case and charges, he was placed on observation for a thorough suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Epstein Found with Loose Noose
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck and was placed on Suicide Watch. He told staff his cellmate, Tartaglione, tried to kill him, but later told the psychologist he did not remember what happened.

events.title: Epstein Reports Fear of Cellmate
events.description: Epstein reported to the psychologist that he was fearful to return to his cell with Tartaglione because Tartaglione had called him a pedophile. He was taken off Suicide Watch and placed on Psychological Observation.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Epstein was transitioned back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) from Psychological Observation. The psychologist emphasized the importance of him having a cellmate for safety reasons.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: Epstein signed a new will. The psychologist stated that had she known, it would have been considered a red flag and Epstein would have been placed on Psychological Observation.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY, 10007 (US Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein underwent three suicide risk assessments during his time at MCC, which was described as unusual.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck. He initially told staff his cellmate, Tartaglione, tried to kill him, but later claimed not to remember the incident.
The Chief Psychologist presented three hypotheses for the noose incident: 1) 'Gaming' the system by Epstein or Tartaglione, 2) A suicide rehearsal by Epstein, or 3) An assault by Tartaglione.
Prison policy emphasized housing SHU inmates with a cellmate to decrease isolation, provide a distraction, and enable a rescue opportunity, but Epstein was ultimately found dead without a cellmate.
The psychologist was unaware Epstein had signed a new will on August 8, 2019, stating that knowledge of this would have been a red flag leading to him being placed on Psychological Observation.
